Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: A Unified System Theoretic Framework for Cyber Attack-Resilient Power Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The electric power grid is a complex cyber-physical system, whose reliable and secure operation is of paramount importance to national security and economic vitality. There is a growing and evolving threat of cyber-based attacks, both in numbers and sophistication, on the nation's critical infrastructure. Therefore, cyber security "encompassing attack prevention, detection, mitigation, and resilience" is critical in today's power grid and the emerging smart grid. The goal of this project is to develop a unified system-theoretic framework and analytical tools for cyber-physical security of power systems, capturing the dynamics of the physical system as well as that of the cyber system. Research tasks include: 1) Development of a methodology for impact analysis that includes systematic identification of worst-case stealthy attacks on the power system's wide-area control and evaluating the resulting consequences in terms of stability violations and performance loss. 2) Development of robust cyber-physical countermeasures, employing a combination of methods from system theory, cyber security, and model-based/data-driven tools, in the form of domain-specific anomaly detection/tolerance algorithms and attack-resilient control algorithms. 3) Evaluating the effectiveness of the proposed impact modeling and mitigation algorithms through a combination of simulation and testbed-based evaluations, using realistic system topologies and attack scenarios. The project makes significant contributions to enhance the security and resiliency of the power grid and lays a scientific foundation for cyber-physical security of critical infrastructure. Also, the project develops novel curriculum modules, mentors graduate and undergraduate students including under-represented minorities, leverages industrial collaborations, and exposes high school students to cyber security concepts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The proposal has resulted in the discovery of a systematic framework for the modeling, impact characterization, and mitigation of attacks in networked cyber physical systems. A theoretical framework was developed for vulnerability analysis to coordinated attacks of large-scale dynamical networks. Targeted malicious attacks for maximal controllability and observability degradation in dynamical networks were investigated, with application to link removal attacks in power networks. Markov jump linear systems were used to model simultaneous attacks on the network's links and nodes. For network monitoring and the estimation of time-varying parameters, optimal sensor collaboration strategies and temporal schedules were uncovered. For the design of coupling architectures in power networks and the smart grid, optimal sparse communication and interaction topologies in networks of synchronizing oscillators were found. A systematic algorithm for optimal consensus-based clustering and community detection was developed for the partitioning of power networks and identifying slow-coherent areas for islanding under contingencies. For the purpose of analyzing and mitigating cascading failures, a class of dynamical Boolean networks was considered in which nodes/agents take binary 0-1 values to characterize whether they are healthy or have failed. Boolean polynomials were used to develop a theoretical framework for the analysis and synthesis of such networks. Application of methods from robust optimization will allow the tractable design of Boolean networks that are resilient against cascading failures.

Broader Impact: The systematic theoretical and computational framework developed in this proposal for the analysis and robust control of network dynamical systems is applicable  to the problem of stability in power systems with stochastic renewable uncertainty. Advancements made in solving non-convex robust optimization problems can be used to mitigate cascading failures under a variety of dynamical models and to provide an optimal global solution of the OPF problem in the presence of renewable uncertainty.  The models, algorithms, and optimization methods developed through this proposal will continue to be integrated into graduate courses at both Syracuse University and Iowa State University.
